We didn't do that, but the article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in the news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) First, let's look at the law. It is called the Makarn Walter Act, not the Makarn Warner Act, which is in fact the Immigration and Nationality Act 1952. Her name is Pat McCaran, then a member of the Democratic Senate from Nevada, Francis Walter, and then a democratic representative from Pennsylvania. Both men are concerned about communists who infiltrate the country through the immigration system, and they wanted to limit who could come to the United States. The resulting law codifyes an existing quota system for immigration. It has also introduced a new system that gives preference to some migrants based on their skills and whether they will be reunited with their families. Since the U.S. Department of State is the Office of Historical Observations, the new law revised the national quota system of origin in 1924 by accepting persons of different nationalities in the United States at the rate of 6 per cent of any many immigrants from a country that lived in the United States in 1920. This means that 85 per cent of some 154,000 visas are granted annually to persons of Northern and Western European descent. President Harry Truman is concerned that the law was discriminatory, but Congress has enough votes to override the veto. The law does not refer to religion or Muslims. Nor does it prevent Muslims from taking office. But over the years, according to the story of 1990 in The New York Times, it has been used to prevent entry into the United States of people such as the writer Gabriel García Marquez and Ian Smith, former Prime Minister of Rhodesia.
